repnme.cdata!: Solomon Islands - Health Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Solomon Islands Health
            Sector Development Project were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: close coordination with
            development partners to ensure coherence and
            complementarities of activities was critical. Establishing
            strong working relationship with development partners,
            especially AusAID, was key to ensuring pre-financing and
            therefore continuity of priority activities during
            suspension of disbursements. Financing some training
            activities and arranging alternative financing during the
            suspension period was essential to keeping the project
            going. Stakeholders' involvement throughout project
            life is crucial. Local empowerment for planning and
            implementing locally developed work plans results in greater
            ownership, commitment and transparency. Finally, ownership
            and dedication by the Project Coordination Committee, which
            met on a regular basis, demonstrated commitment to the
            objectives of the project and was essential to ensuring that
            the project did not collapse during the lengthy period of
            instability in the country.

5084703.trustfund:
TF020584-AUSAID- HEALTH SECTOR SUPPORT
            (SOLOMON ISLAND),TF026243-PHRD-HEALTH SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF025426-PHRD: HEALTH SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF037961-PACIFIC ISLANDS - SOLOMON ISL,
            SAMOA, PAPUA NEW GUINEA, HEALTH

repnme.cdata!: Solomon Islands - Health Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Development Project,
            will assist the Government of the Solomon Islands improve
            rural communities' health, by strengthening
            reproductive health and malaria programs, through new
            testing methods, and improved planning, management, and
            monitoring of priority health programs. The project
            components call for: a) improved reproductive health, in
            provincial services, focusing on training for medical, and
            nursing staff, including clinical supervision, and upgrading
            of rural health facilities. International assessment, and
            monitoring guidelines for health quality will be adapted,
            and, an inter-sectoral task force, with provincial
            representation will provide feedback to the Ministry of
            Health and Medical Services (MHMS); b) improved malaria
            prevention and control, which will provide funds for the
            National Malaria Control Program, while improving analysis
            and monitoring, of factors affecting program success, while
            improving its effectiveness. An inter-sectoral task force
            will support, and fund pilot studies for an improved
            community response; c) capacity building, to strengthen the
            MHMS institutional capacity in health planning, emphasizing
            health management information systems, monitoring
            evaluation/research, and, donor coordination; and, d)
            project coordination and management, which will provide
            support functions, including financial, and procurement management.
